EmoteActions.Message: Verdentine studies the Silk for a moment.

Yes, a high quality Silk! Looks like you could go and get some more now if you like, but after that I must insist that you not try and harvest more Silk from the Grievvers for at least two weeks. I'm concerned about the colonies well being as I'm sure are you.
Here's your Silk back. Do you know of the two machines able to spin fine materials like this into cloth?
I've read of a Spinning Wheel found in a Castle to the Northeast of Shoushi overrun by skeletons and there was a Loom found in a food cellar at Neydisa Castle.
You might try seeing if you can fashion this Silk into something of use.
Farewell my friend, I am only just beginning to uncover the secrets of how the Grievvers social structure works and I must get back to my observations so as not to miss anything.
%n writes something into a book of notes, mutters a bit and continues writing.
What are they up to?
Fascinating!

Did you see that!? One of the Grievvers just motioned as if to warn another one! Perhaps this is a basic form of non-verbal communication or maybe a hierarchical order, I must record this and study it further.
Remarkable creatures!
GrievverSilk
GrievverSilk

So, you were able to get the Spinning Wheel to make this? Wonderful! And very strong thread too. Are you going to see what the Loom at Neydisa Castle might do with it? This is wonderful, now that grievvers can provide us with Silk, perhaps people will take my work more seriously.
Such fine craftsmanship. You say the Loom at Neydisa Castle made this? Fascinating what machines can do.
If I weren't so interested in Grievvers and Olthoi I might consider studying these magical devices, perhaps in time I will grow tired of them...
Oh, look here, you have something on your flag. I'll just wash that out for you.
All clean, here you go.
Verdentine holds the Olthoi Head up reverently peering through the eyeholes.
The Olthoi is a marvel of nature. I would love to see the world they can from, their natural environment must be very harsh and demanding to require so much armor.

Have you thought of making a helmet out of this? I have a friend who crafts items from Olthoi trophies. She lives in Newic, I'm sure she would be happy to make this into a helm for you. She's known as the Olthoi Hunter.
The researcher hefts the claw in his hands.

Extremely lightweight, yet amazingly strong and look at the sharp edge here. They can pierce armor with these things as easily as you do with a sword. Speaking of which, you can have this crafted into a sword by my friend who still lives in Newic. Her name is... come to think of it, I don't know her name. Huh! Everyone just calls her the Olthoi Hunter.
Verdentine eyes grow extremely wide as he surveys the Olthoi Carapace you hand him.
Did you take this from a Queen?
For a brief moment Verdentine looks extremely dangerous, then the anger drains from his features leaving a look of sad resignation.
I wasn't sure if the rumors were true... Now I'll never be able to see her alive, I can only hope that she wasn't the last.
You must be quite a skilled hunter to have recovered this whole. I just can't get over the size of this Carapace... Thank you for showing it to me.

I've heard of these. Apparently they are quite valuable on Marae Lassel. I really need to take a trip to that island to study it's Olthoi. I've even heard rumors of a new Olthoi Queen. There just isn't enough time is there? Oh well, my work here is fascinating too.
Verdentine hands the pincer back to you.
Very interesting, thank you.

I've heard of these. Apparently they are quite valuable on Marae Lassel. I really must to take a trip to that island to study it's Olthoi. I've even heard rumors of a new Olthoi Queen. There just isn't enough time is there? Oh well, my work here is fascinating too.
Verdentine hands the pincer back to you.
Very interesting, thank you.

I've heard of these. Apparently they are quite valuable on Marae Lassel. I really must to take a trip to that island to study it's Olthoi. I've even heard rumors of a new Olthoi Queen. There just isn't enough time is there? Oh well, my work here is fascinating too.
Verdentine hands the pincer back to you.
Very interesting, thank you.

I've heard of these. Apparently they are quite valuable on Marae Lassel. I really must to take a trip to that island to study it's Olthoi. I've even heard rumors of a new Olthoi Queen. There just isn't enough time is there? Oh well, my work here is fascinating too.
Verdentine hands the pincer back to you.
Very interesting, thank you.

I've heard of these. Apparently they are quite valuable on Marae Lassel. I really must to take a trip to that island to study it's Olthoi. I've even heard rumors of a new Olthoi Queen. There just isn't enough time is there? Oh well, my work here is fascinating too.
Verdentine hands the pincer back to you.
Very interesting, thank you.
I don't know how to feel about this. You have managed to kill this unique and marvelous Lady.

I am joyed to be able to examine this specimen, but I also feel anger and sorrow at the possibility that you may have doomed the Olthoi species of this land. Do we have more of a right to this world than they? Who is to say? I know the Olthoi enslaved us. I know they kill us. I just don't think that exterminating them is the only answer.
I am sorry I did not mean to place a burden on your shoulders. You have done a mighty deed for sure.
%n holds the mounted head at arms length. His face contorts in sorrow for a brief moment.
I am... joyed to be able to examine this specimen. I'm sure tales of your deed will be told for years to come. A fine mounting job, Tumerok craftsmanship if I'm not mistaken.

Ah yes, an original Olthoi Helm. My friend the Olthoi Hunter no doubt made this for you quite a long time ago. It truly is a classic design. May it serve you well, at least better than it served its original owner.
Haha, it's not often I have company to laugh with.

A newer version of my friend's famous helm. Look at that craftsmanship! He uses the Olthoi head's natural strengths and adds to them where the shell is weakest. A beautiful helm. You are very lucky to own one.

Here we have one of the most beautiful examples of natural armor. The Olthoi Carapace is perfectly suited to resisting heavy blows and attacks as well as sharp piercing strikes. This cuirass is lighter than most and stronger too, a fine piece of work. Thank you for allowing me to study it, may it protect you always.
%n hefts the weapon in his hand and examines the blades black luster.
A blade lighter than steel and sharper than most non-magical weapons.
Odd that you can fight Olthoi with their own appendages. You would think it would cause them some confusion as well... Perhaps it just makes them angry. A fine sword!
You experience a slight queasy feeling watching Verdentine eat the cake.
Mmmmm chocolate, and you can taste the Olthoi!
Verdentine pokes a hole in the egg with his finger. He eyes the contents for a second and then tips the egg to his mouth and drinks it down.
A wave of nausea washes over you.
Delicious! And it will keep me going while I'm out here in the field. Thank you.
How Clever! It's really a very good likeness of an Olthoi. What will they think of next?
Oh, right, you want your doll back. Here, take it.
Oh! It's not real! Haha, very funny. Of course you wouldn't think it so funny if you had been bitten by one of the little nippers.
Oh, this isn't mine to keep? Well, have it back I guess.

I see you've harvested some of the rare Grievver Acid. Very powerful stuff! I sometimes use it to clean my armor up. By the way, don't open this anywhere around here. If the Grievvers pick up on it they could cause you no end of trouble.

Haha, just kidding! I know what this stuff is and I very seriously doubt I would like the taste of it. However be forewarned, I wouldn't open this here if I were you. The Grievvers have a fierce dislike of the Olthoi and I'm afraid that the smell of this stuff, if in fact Grievvers can smell, would bring them running in droves.
No, I can't have a campfire. It might attract the Grievvers.
Small price to pay really.
I recently tried to get recognition at the Arcanum for my work on Grievvers. Do you know what they told me?

They said chasing bugs is "just an eccentric hobby" not worthy of funding. Well, I don't need the Queen's backing. I'm sure that my work will bear fruit and prove it's worth to those skeptics someday.
I have a theory on how Grievvers perceive the world. They have no evident visual organs, yet they seem to move about quite easily.

From what I have learned and deduced I believe Grievvers come from the same world as the Olthoi, but unlike the Olthoi they were bent to the will of the Shadows. This undoubtedly changed them in ways I cannot say. Perhaps they used to have eyes, perhaps not, I think they may use magics now to attain a view of the world. If so, they can probably see things that we cannot. Or it may be that they have a heightened sense of smell that which allows them to move about and find prey.
At some point I may try and get a specimen to dissect and learn more, but my work here is currently more important.
%n gazes dreamily into the distance.

Imagine having the abilities of a Grievver! You could climb almost any surface. Your strength would be magnified many times that of a normal human. You could spin webs, although that seems rather useless unless you want to catch your lunch... You reactions would be enhanced and you might have senses beyond those we are aware of.
I know that sounds silly, but I often daydream about such things.
Did you see that? A little Grievver! I wonder if it's a different species or just a juvenile.
I fear that they may detect my camp here on the hill and figure out a way up. I'm not much of a fighter I'm afraid.

This I know for a fact. The Grievvers cannot abide the presence of Olthoi. They will fight fiercely against them whenever the two come in contact. This leads me to believe that the Grievvers and Olthoi share some common origin.

Grievvers eat whatever they can catch. I often see them dragging rabbits, aurochs and other creatures wrapped in webbing across the valley floor. Yesterday I saw them drag an injured Olthoi to the east of the valley where I expect they have a nest of sorts. Unfortunately, many young warriors and mages new to the world also fall prey to the Grievvers out of inexperience.

What? A minor setback? Ah yes, the lifestones. You wouldn't think that was any worse than the hundreds of other ways we can die and be reborn anew into this world, but Grievvers prefer to eat their food alive I'm afraid. They try to injure their prey and cocoon it for consumption at their convenience. I... I sometimes hear horrible sounds from down there. Be careful here, I beg you.

I believe that the Grievvers have a complex social order. I can often see one deferring to another in combat or during feeding. Yet it doesn't appear to be a purely physical hierarchy since I've seen a smaller Grievver receive deferential treatment. Perhaps they also recognize intelligence or magical ability as dominating traits. It's all very interesting!

I am very interested in insect trophies and body parts. You can learn much about a creature from its remains. If you have any I would greatly enjoy looking them over. Don't worry I'll return them after I've examined them. I do however have a powerful appetite and cannot make the same assurances about food. Haha!

I'm afraid I find the recent Grievver activity in this valley somewhat unsettling. They seem to guard the area against all other creatures. I've never seen Grievvers build a nest, but I think that's just what they are doing. Perhaps the lack of Shadow influence for so long is allowing them to return to a more natural existence. If you think yourself brave enough I would be very grateful to know what they are doing in the far east of the valley.
Verdentine takes the Silk and fluffs it in his hands.
That's some very nice Silk! Got it from a Grievver you say? Well you shouldn't try and get anymore for at least two weeks. We have to think about conservation don't we?

Here you go. Very interesting substance, it's a much finer quality than the webbing I've seen all over the valley. You know, I've heard of two machines able to spin fine materials like this into cloth. I seem to remember they were both found in Castles somewhere... let me check my notes.
Yes, here it is!

It says here that there was a Spinning Wheel found in a Castle to the Northeast of Shoushi overrun by skeletons... and here it says that a Loom was recently found in a food cellar at Neydisa Castle. The residents dragged it up to a tower room, but were unable to get it to produce any useable cloth.
I think our insect friends have provided you with the materials required. You might try seeing if you can get the devices to work.

Good luck in your travels my friend! I am going to continue my studies of these fascinating creatures here. Please, only kill them out of necessity so as not to disturb the fragile ecological balance in this area.
